case_name: Shri Krishna Madholkar v. University of Gujarat

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 234 and 262 of 1962 were filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 234 and 262 of 1962. Appeals from the judgment

facts.text: Appeals from judgment and order dated January 24, 1962 of Gujarat High Court in Special Civil Application No. 624 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the judgment and order dated January 24, 1962, of the Gujarat High Court in, Special Civil Application No. 624 of 1961.

facts.text: Shrikant son of Shri Krishna Madholkar appeared for Secondary School Certificate examination held by State of Bombay in March 1960 and was declared successful.

anchor.surface_text: SHAH J.-Shrikant son of Shri Krishna Madholkar appeared for the Secondary School Certificate examination held by the State of Bombay in March, 1960, and was declared successful.

facts.text: Shrikant took instruction in subjects through medium of Marathi and answered questions in Marathi.

anchor.surface_text: He took instruction in the various subjects prescribed for the examination through the medium of Marathi  which is his mother-tongue  and answered the questions

facts.text: Shrikant joined St. Xaviers College affiliated to University of Gujarat in First Year Arts class in English medium section.

anchor.surface_text: Shrikant joined the St. Xaviers College affiliated to the University of Gujarat, in the First Year Arts class and was admitted in the section in which instructions were imparted through the medium of English.

facts.text: Shrikant successfully completed First Year Arts course in March 1961.

anchor.surface_text: After successfully companypleting the First Year Arts companyrse in March, 1961, Shrikant applied for admission to the classes preparing for the Intermediate Arts examination

facts.text: Principal of St. Xaviers College informed Shrikant he could not attend English medium classes without University sanction due to Gujarat University Act 1949 and Statutes 207,208,209 amended 1961.

anchor.surface_text: The Principal of the College informed Shrikant that in view of the provisions of the Gujarat University Act, 1949, and the Statutes 207, 208 and 209 framed by the Senate of the Uni- versity, as amended in 1961 he companyld number without the sanction

facts.text: Shri Krishna Madholkar moved Vice-Chancellor for sanction to permit Shrikant English medium classes.

anchor.surface_text: Shri Krishna, father of Shrikant then moved the Vice-Chancellor of the University for sanction to permit Shrikant to attend the English medium classes in the St. Xaviers College.

facts.text: Registrar declined request but allowed English as medium of examination but not for instruction.

anchor.surface_text: The Registrar of the University declined to grant the request, but by another letter Shrikant was allowed to keep English as a medium of examination but number for instruction.

facts.text: Shri Krishna Madholkar filed petition in Gujarat High Court for mandamus challenging ss.4(27), 18(xiv), 38A of Gujarat University Act 1949 and Statutes 207,208,209.

anchor.surface_text: A petition was then filed by Shri Krishna Madholkar on behalf of himself and his minor son Shrikant in the High Court of Gujarat for a writ or order in the nature of Mandamus or other writ, direction or order requiring the University of Gujarat to treat ss. 4 27 , 18  i   xiv  and 38A

facts.text: Gujarat High Court issued writs prayed for on January 24, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court of Gujarat by order dated January 24, 1962, issued the writs prayed for.

facts.text: University of Gujarat and State of Gujarat appealed to Supreme Court with certificates of fitness.

anchor.surface_text: The University and the State of Gujarat have separately appealed to this Court with certificates of fitness granted by the High Court.

facts.text: Gujarat University Act 1949 enacted by Bombay Legislature to establish teaching and affiliating University.

anchor.surface_text: The Legislature of the Province of Bombay enacted the Gujarat University Act, 1949, to establish and incorporate a teaching and affiliating University as a measure of decentralization and re- organisation of University education in the province.

facts.text: St. Xaviers College was affiliated to University of Bombay under Bombay Act 4 of 1928.

anchor.surface_text: St. Xaviers College was affiliated to the University of Bombay under Bombay Act 4 of 1928.

facts.text: By s.5(3) of Gujarat University Act, institutions in Gujarat area deemed affiliated to Gujarat University from prescribed date.

anchor.surface_text: By s. 5 3  of the Act, from the prescribed date all educational institutions admitted to the privileges of the University of Bombay and situate within the University area of Gujarat were deemed to be admitted to the privileges of the University of Gujarat.

facts.text: Statutes 207,208,209 framed in 1954 dealing with media of instruction.

anchor.surface_text: In 1954, the Gujarat University framed certain Regulations dealing with the media of instruction. They are Statutes 207, 208 and 209.

facts.text: Act 4 of 1961 enacted by Gujarat State Legislature amending proviso to s.4(27) and enacting s.38A.

anchor.surface_text: After the companystitution of a separate State of Gujarat, Act 4 of 1961 was enacted by the Gujarat State Legislature. By that Act the proviso to s. 4 27  was amended

facts.text: Senate amended Statutes 207 and 209 after Act 4 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: The Senate of the University thereafter amended Statutes 207 and 209.

facts.text: Registrar issued circular on June 22, 1961 to Principals permitting English medium only for certain students who did Secondary in English and FY in English for 1961-62 only.

anchor.surface_text: The Registrar of the University thereafter issued a Circular on June 22, 1961, addressed to Principals of Affiliated Colleges stating that the Vice-Chancellor in exercise of the powers vested in him under s. 11 4  a  of the Act was pleased to direct that-

facts.text: Shrikant had not appeared at SSC in English medium, so could not use English for instruction under circular.

anchor.surface_text: Shrikant had number appeared at the S.S.C. Examination in the medium of English and under the first clause of the circular he companyld number be permitted by the Principal of the St. Xaviers College to companytinue to use English

facts.text: Supreme Court held University has no power under Gujarat University Act to prescribe Gujarati or Hindi as exclusive medium of instruction.

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly agree with the High Court that power to impose Gujarati or Hindi or both as an exclusive medium or media has number been companyferred under cl.  27  or any other clauses of s. 4.

facts.text: Supreme Court held amendment to proviso of s.4(27) by Act 4 of 1961 valid.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable, however, to agree with the High Court that Act 4 of 1961 in so far as it amended the proviso to s. 4  27  is invalid, because it is beyond the companypetence of the State Legislature.

facts.text: Supreme Court held s.38A invalid as University has no power to prescribe exclusive medium.

anchor.surface_text: If the University have numberpower to prescribe an exclusive medium, the enactment of s. 38A which prescribes penalties for failing to carry out directions relating to the media of instruction will doubtless be number invalid.

facts.text: Supreme Court declined to decide on infringement of Articles 29(1) and 30(1) due to lack of pleading and evidence.

anchor.surface_text: We have declined to hear arguments about the alleged infringement of fundamental rights under Articles 29  1  and 30  1  by the Act assuming as it authorises imposition of Gujarati or Hindi as an exclusive medium of instruction, for, in our view, the petition suffers from a singular lack of pleading

holdings.text: The University has no power under the Gujarat University Act, 1949 to prescribe Gujarati or Hindi or both as an exclusive medium or media of instruction and examination in affiliated colleges.

anchor.surface_text: We do not, having regard to the phraseology used by the Legislature, agree with the High Court that this power is restricted in its exercise to institutions set up by the University

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of s.4 clauses (1,2,7,8,10,14,27,28) and s.18(xiv) shows no express or implied power to impose exclusive medium; 'promote ... as a medium' means one among several, not exclusive; agrees with High Court.

holdings.text: Statutes 207, 208 and 209 are ultra vires and invalid insofar as they impose Gujarati or Hindi as exclusive media of instruction.

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly agree with the High Court that power to impose Gujarati or Hindi or both as an exclusive medium or media has not been conferred under cl. 27 or any other clauses of s. 4.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Since no power conferred on University, Senate cannot enact statutes imposing exclusive medium beyond Act's scope.

holdings.text: Act 4 of 1961 amending the proviso to s.4(27) is valid and within State legislative competence.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable, however, to agree with the High Court that Act 4 of 1961 in so far as it amended the proviso to s. 4(27) is invalid, because it is beyond the competence of the State Legislature.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Amendment merely extends existing English medium beyond 10 years in specified subjects/courses; does not lower standards or affect coordination under Entry 66.

holdings.text: Section 38A of the Gujarat University Act, 1949 is valid.

anchor.surface_text: If the University have no power to prescribe an exclusive medium, the enactment of s. 38A which prescribes penalties for failing to carry out directions relating to the media of instruction will doubtless be not invalid.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.38A provides penalties for non-compliance with media directions generally; not dependent solely on exclusive medium power; sets aside HC declaration of invalidity.

holdings.text: The petitioner has the right to maintain the petition under Article 226 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: we refuse to decide the question not because the petitioner had no right to maintain the petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution as contended by the University. and the State of Gujarat, but because of the paucity

holdings.reasoning_summary: Refusal to decide Arts 29/30 issue due to paucity of pleadings/evidence, explicitly not due to lack of locus standi.

holdings.text: State Legislature has power under Entry 11 List II to prescribe medium of instruction including exclusive medium, subject to Entries 63-66 List I; invalid if prejudicially affects coordination/determination of standards under Entry 66.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction of Entries 11 List II and 66 List I; pith and substance doctrine; State power over education includes medium as incident, but Union overrides if impacts standards/coordination; academic expression for guidance.

holdings.text: A University has implied power to indicate a medium of instruction but not to impose an exclusive medium absent express provision.

anchor.surface_text: A corporation has ordinarily an implied power to carry out its objects power to indicate a medium of instruction in affiliated or constituent colleges

holdings.reasoning_summary: Corporations have implied powers for objects, but imposing exclusive medium requires express statutory authority.

precedents.citation: Hingir-Rampur Coal Company v. State of Orissa 1

anchor.surface_text: In Hingir-Rampur Coal Company v. State of Orissa 1 , this Court in companysidering the import of the expression subject to used in an entry in List II, in relation to an entry in List I observed that to the extent of the restriction imposed by the use of the expression subject to in an entry in List II, the power is taken away from the State Legislature.

precedents.case_name: Hingir-Rampur Coal Company v. State of Orissa
precedents.cited_proposition: to the extent of the restriction imposed by the use of the expression 'subject to' in an entry in List II in relation to an entry in List I, the power is taken away from the State Legislature
precedents.cited_holding: to the extent of the restriction imposed by the use of the expression subject to in an entry in List II, the power is taken away from the State Legislature

precedents.citation: Prafulla Kumar v. Bank of Commerce, Khulna 1

anchor.surface_text: The judicial Committee, in Prafulla Kumar v. Bank of Commerce, Khulna 1 , had invoked the principle of pith and substance to ascertain whether the Bengal Money-lenders Act  X of 1940  was ultra vires the Provincial Legislature.

precedents.case_name: Prafulla Kumar v. Bank of Commerce, Khulna
precedents.cited_proposition: principle of pith and substance for resolving overlapping legislative fields; validity determined by true nature and character of the enactment
precedents.cited_holding: But the overlapping of subject-matter is not avoided by substituting three lists for two or even by arranging for a hierarchy of jurisdiction. Subjects must still overlap and where they do the question must be asked what in pith and substance is the effect of the enactment-of which complaint is made and in what list is its true nature and character to be found.

precedents.citation: The State of Bombay v. F. N. Balsara 1

anchor.surface_text: This Court, in The State of Bombay v. F. N. Balsara 1 , has accepted that principle. There, the constitutional validity of the Bombay Prohibition Act  XXV of 1949  was in issue.

precedents.case_name: State of Bombay v. F.N. Balsara
precedents.cited_proposition: pith and substance determines legislative competence even if incidental encroachment on another field

precedents.citation: A. S. Krishna v. The State of Madras 1

anchor.surface_text: This Court again had to deal with the vires of the provisions of the Madras Prohibition Act in A. S. Krishna v. The State of Madras 1 . There, the argument was that the said provisions were repugnant to the provisions of the existing Indian laws

precedents.case_name: A.S. Krishna v. State of Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: if a statute relates in substance to a topic within competence, it is intra vires even if it incidentally trenches on other topics
precedents.cited_holding: That is to say, if a statute is found in substance to relate to a topic within the competence of the legislature, it should be held to be intra vires, even though it might incidentally trench on topics not within its legislative competence.

precedents.citation: Union Colliery Company of British Columbia, Ltd. v. Bryden 2

anchor.surface_text: But it is said that the separate existence of the doctrine of direct impact was conceded in Union Colliery Company of British Columbia, Ltd. v. Bryden 2  . There, the question was whether s.4 of the British Columbia Coal Mines Regulation Act

precedents.case_name: Union Colliery Company of British Columbia Ltd. v. Bryden
precedents.cited_proposition: pith and substance applies; law prohibiting employment of aliens in mines trenches on federal power over aliens
precedents.cited_holding: the whole pith and substance of the enactments of s. 4 of the Coal Mines Regulation Act... consists in establishing a statutory prohibition which affects aliens or naturalised subjects, and therefore trench upon the exclusive authority of the Parliament of Canada.

anchor.surface_text: In Bank of Toronto v. Lambe 1  the Quebec Act was attacked on two grounds, first that the tax was not taxation within the Province, and secondly, that the tax was not a direct tax.

precedents.cited_proposition: legislative power within competence not invalidated by possibility of abuse or limitation on other powers
precedents.cited_holding: If the judges find that on the due construction of the Act a legislative power falls within s. 92, it would be quite wrong of them to deny its existence because by some possibility it may be abused, or may limit the range which otherwise would be open to the Dominion Parliament.

precedents.citation: Attorney-General for Alberta v. Attorney-General for Canada 2

anchor.surface_text: This case was considered and distinguished in Attorney-General for Alberta v. Attorney-General for Canada 2 . There, the Province of Alberta passed an Act respecting the taxation of Banks

precedents.case_name: Attorney-General for Alberta v. Attorney-General for Canada
precedents.cited_proposition: provincial tax on banks was colourable legislation interfering with federal banking power, not true provincial taxation
precedents.cited_holding: instead of being in any true sense taxation in order to the raising of a revenue for Provincial purposes, the Bill No. 1 is merely part of a legislative plan to prevent the operation within the Province of those banking institutions

precedents.citation: Calcutta Gas Company v. The State of West Bengal 1

anchor.surface_text: In Calcutta Gas 1 Company v. The State of West Bengal 1 , it is observed The power to legislate is given to the appropriate Legislatures by Art. 246 of the Constitution.

precedents.case_name: Calcutta Gas Company v. State of West Bengal
precedents.cited_proposition: entries are legislative heads; widest amplitude to language; reconcile conflicting entries to bring harmony
precedents.cited_holding: The entries in the three Lists are only legislative heads or fields of legislation they demarcate the area over which the appropriate Legislatures can operate. ... every attempt should be made to harmonize the apparently conflicting entries not only of different Lists but also of the same List

anchor.surface_text: The order of the High Court relating to the invalidity of the Statutes 207 and 209 of the University in so far as they purport to impose Gujarati or Hindi or both as exclusive medium or media of instruction, and the circulars enforcing those statutes must therefore be confirmed. We do not express any opinion on the alleged infringement of fundamental rights of the petitioner under Arts. 29(1), 30(1) of the Constitution.

outcome.relief_summary: Confirmed High Court order declaring Statutes 207 and 209 invalid insofar as imposing exclusive Gujarati/Hindi medium and circulars enforcing them; set aside High Court declaration of invalidity of proviso to s.4 cl.27 and s.38A; no opinion on Arts.29(1) and 30(1); appellants to pay respondents' costs.
directions: Appellants will pay the costs of the respondents in the two appeals.
